title: What is the best book to learn circuit analysis? - Quora

response.answer_text: Previous answers either mentioned introductory circuit analysis texts — which are found in many incarnations, all of them more or less clones of a same syllabus, to fulfill needs of university courses :-) — or they mentioned “books on electronics”, mainly Sedra’s “Microelectronics” and the “Art of Electronics”. But electronics books are not books on circuit analysis… Well, IMHO the best book to learn circuit analysis is “Linear and Nonlinear Circuits” from Chua, Desoer and Kuh (CDK) (Leon O. Chua, Charles A. Desoer, Ernest S. Kuh: 9780070108981: Amazon.com: Books ). After that one, comes what can be considered the “previous edition”: “Basic Circuit Theory” from Desoer & Kuh (Charles A. Desoer: 9780070165755: Amazon.com: Books ), although it is a few notches down due to the far weaker (read incomplete) treatment of nonlinear circuits. The reason why CDK is the best IMO is because no book I am aware of treats systematically, and explains in a clear way (chapters 2, 3 and 4, mostly), the analysis of nonlinear circuits, both resistive and dynamic, including (simple) examples of the analysis of nonlinear dynamic circuits. About 20~30 years ago CDK was the recommended text in the introductory course on “circuit analysis” in my school (IST, the largest engineering school in Lisbon, Portugal) and I used it (along with Colclaser’s Electronics text Basic Principles: Roy A. Colclaser, etc.: 9780471866268: Amazon.com: Books for analog electronics and Digital Circuits and Microprocessors (McGraw-Hill series in electrical engineering. Computer engineering and switching theory) for digital electronics) to teach “Introduction to circuits and electronics” in other school, with excellent results: the students learned to do easily and systematically the large signal analysis of nonlinear circuits — e.g. circuits with diodes, resistors and sources, with 3 or 4 diodes. This kind of analysis is perhaps the most difficult to grasp for electronics rookies: electronics texts jdon’t teach you how to do a systematic quantitative analysis, they just present a qualitative discussion of the “standard” configurations: rectifiers, limiters, clampers, nonlinear shapers,… CDK also introduces the basic methods for simulation of large scale circuits — Newton-Raphson for nonlinear resistive circuits, forward and backward Euler for integrating nonlinear differential-algebraic equations modeling nonlinear dynamic circuits. Unfortunately, CDK was (or is) too advanced for its time :-) and so, it is out of print since many years. Even used copies are usually expensive. Fortunately, at the time I bought a few paperback copies for myself which often serve me well :-) (PS: a few time ago I answered about the “5 books an EE should read” and it became a popular answer: Jose Soares Augusto's answer to What are the top five books every Electrical Engineer should study at least once? Perhaps you have some interest on it…)

I have to disagree with Art of Electronics - it’s great but it’s too disorganized and goes too deep in many cases. If learning circuit analysis well and quickly matters, it’s definitely NOT the best book. AFTER you’ve learned circuit analysis, it does better as “leisurely read” or a “I have a specific issue not found in textbooks” or “I want to learn something I didn’t know before” type of resource. Various tomes by Robert Boylestad are still the best for basic circuit analysis. I used the 1968 edition of Introductory Circuit Analysis when I was a teen. In EE school we used Boylestad/Nashalsky Introductory Circuit Analysis. There’s a lot of overlap between all of his books and all are good for basic circuit theory. Introductory Circuit Analysis Electronic Devices and Circuit Theory: Louis Nashelsky Robert L. Boylestad: 9781292025636: Amazon.com: Books
